Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Manuscript Division

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Author, journalist, news analyst, and government official. Correspondence, manuscripts of articles and early pieces of fiction, subject file, radio scripts, biographical material, lectures and speeches, and photographs relating to Davis's career.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

persname.part: Davis, Elmer Holmes, 1890-1958. But We Were Born Free. 1954.

corpname.part: United States. Office of War Information.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The papers of Elmer Holmes Davis, author, journalist, news analyst, and government official, were given to the Library of Congress by Davis and his widow, Florence MacMillan Davis, in 1954 and 1959. A letter was given by William R. Allen in 1962 and a radio script by Reid and Nancy Campbell Joyner in 2011.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The papers of Elmer Holmes Davis were arranged and described circa 1960. The 1953 letter given by William R. Allen was interfiled into the collection in 1962. The finding aid was revised in 2004. The collection was expanded and the finding aid revised in 2012.

otherfindaid.head: Additional Guides
otherfindaid.p: A note on the Elmer Holmes Davis Papers appeared in the Library's Information Bulletin 18, no. 20 (May 18, 1959): 269-70. A brief description of the papers also appeared in the Library's Quarterly Journal of Current Acquisitions 17, no. 3 (May 1960): 185.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Copyright in the unpublished writings of Elmer Holmes Davis in these papers and in other collections of papers in the custody of the Library of Congress has been dedicated to the public.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Elmer Holmes Davis are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, Elmer Holmes Davis Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: A.B. and A.M., Franklin College, Franklin, Ind.
Rhodes Scholar, Queen's College, Oxford University, Oxford, England
Worked on staff of New York Times
Created and wrote for the character Godfrey G. Gloom, who was a columnist and political commentator
Free-lance writer, radio commentator, and lecturer
Published But We Were Born Free . Garden City, New York: Garden City Books
Published Two Minutes Till Midnight , a sequel to But We Were Born Free . Indianapolis, Indiana: Bobbs-Merrill

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p:
The papers of Elmer Holmes Davis (1890-1958) span the years 1865-1957, with the bulk of the material dating from 1946 to 1955. The papers are organized into the following series:
General Correspondence ,
Personal and Literary File ,
Subject File ,
Radio Scripts , and
Addition .

The
General Correspondence contains mostly letters relating to Davis's career. He kept little of his personal incoming and outgoing letters. Davis did, however, retain some early correspondence written by his parents, his wife, and a few others. Notable are the 1917 letters from Carolyn A. Wilson who reported from France during World War I for the Chicago Tribune and corresponded with Davis about what she observed. Later correspondence reflects Davis's involvement in the political and literary fields. Correspondents include Bernard Augustine De Voto, Edward R. Murrow, Harold Wallace Ross, James Thurber, Harry S. Truman, Hendrik Willem van Loon, Sumner Welles, and William Allen White.

The
Personal and Literary File contains biographical material, lectures and speeches, photographs, and printed copies of many of Davis's articles and early pieces of fiction as well as the typescript of But We Were Born Free . Of interest are photographs taken during a visit to Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, in 1944, and currency produced by the First National Bank of Aurora, Indiana, in 1865, where Davis's father worked.

The
Subject File , devoted mainly to world events, contains correspondence, newspaper clippings, magazine articles, government publications, notes, and press releases issued by news bureaus and government agencies. Of interest are the files on the Office of War Information that include a report to the president for the years 1942-1945 and items relating to Davis's service as director including his file card from the Nazi Propaganda Ministry, memoranda of conversations with government officials, and correspondence and clippings relating to the dispute between the Office of War Information and its overseas branch. Further correspondence relating to the Office of War Information is in the General Correspondence.

Radio Scripts contains Davis's original scripts of broadcasts for the Columbia Broadcasting System and the American Broadcasting Company. For 1946, there is also a set of approved scripts. The
Addition is comprised of a radio script dated 16 February 1942.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in five series:

scopecontent.p: Biographical and family material, clippings, speeches and lectures, memorabilia, photographs, articles, typescript of his book But We Were Born Free , booklets, a novel, and short stories.

arrangement.p: Arranged under personal or literary and therein by type of material.

did.unittitle: Currency and documents relating to Elam Holmes Davis (father), 1865, 1873, 1888, 1896, 1912-1913
Transcripts from the British Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System, 1948-1949
Book, But We Were Born Free , typescript, 1954

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, clippings, congressional reports, notes, press releases, printed matter, research papers, and other material.
